Roger.Action: Turns off the TV to give Elaine his full attention and cuddles with her.
Expresses sincere feelings about commitment and not wanting to mislead Elaine.
Turns off the TV to focus on Elaine's serious conversation, expresses thoughtful consideration about their future together, and communicates honestly about his feelings.
Is engrossed in a game and does not respond to Elaine's serious question about their future together.
Rolls over and goes back to sleep despite the rooster crowing, showing reluctance or lack of initiative.
Nods sleepily at other primates and carries a large jagged rock slab with them, participating in group activity.
Greets others with a friendly 'Whassup?'
Politely asks to look at Pete's round rock and handles it with interest and respect.
Politely asks to examine the round rock from Primate Pete, showing curiosity and willingness to learn.
Carries a jagged rock slab like the others, following the group's approach without questioning its effectiveness.
Questions how to skin a wildebeest with the jagged rock slabs, showing curiosity and engagement in problem-solving.
Does not offer a solution or contribute further after questioning, indicating a lack of follow-through or initiative.
Tries to keep noise down for the kids' sake.
Dismisses Elaine's concern about kids being hungry and the practicalities of hunting and preparing food.
Insists on using jagged rock slabs despite Elaine's concerns about practicality and the kids' hunger.
Throws the rock slab up in the air, which transforms into a modern Windows device, showing imaginative thinking and vision.
Confidently explains the features of the new device (holding a Windows device) and its advantages over a traditional address book.
Spends a large amount of money without discussing it first with Elaine.
Looks a little nervous when questioned by the Colonial Reporter.
Spends five hundred dollars without discussing it first with Elaine.
Claims a device can do both email and address book functions, showing some tech awareness.
Refuses to ask for directions, insisting on taking a shortcut despite Elaine's doubts.
Appears nervous when interviewed as Colonial Roger, showing lack of confidence in public speaking.
Points out the person responsible for the idea when asked by the reporter, answers questions without hesitation.
Denies responsibility for the Greek letters painted on his chest but asks the reporter not to tell anyone, showing some awareness of social consequences.
Denies having a girlfriend and looks away when teased, then endures continued punching from other boys without retaliation.
Denies having a girlfriend and avoids confrontation by saying 'Nothing!' when questioned, then resumes punching behavior with others.
Downplays his injury to avoid worrying Elaine, insists it's just a sprain.
Interrupts and tells coworkers to stop their argument, indicating desire for peace.
Downplays his injury confidently by insisting it's just a sprain despite appearances.
Interrupts and commands the arguing coworkers to stop, showing assertiveness and control.
Fails to engage meaningfully in the argument about the athlete's record, showing limited insight or contribution.
Encourages playful competition among friends by joining the footrace.
Refuses to seek medical help despite injury, downplays his pain.
Challenges others confidently by claiming he can run the forty in under six seconds.
Participates in a risky footrace despite apparent physical limitations or lack of preparation, resulting in injury.
Refuses to seek medical help for a serious injury, insisting it will 'work itself out' despite obvious incapacity.
Remembers and accurately repeats that Gene's dad is really sick when Elaine asks about it.
Questions Elaine about the magazines she brought, showing awareness and engagement.
Does not elaborate or attempt to draw Gene out further despite Elaine's instructions, showing limited initiative.
Shares interest in Gene's SEGA cartridges and shows genuine curiosity about Gene's gaming achievements.
Asks Gene about the 'Evil Presence' and respects Gene's uncertainty without pressuring him.
Examines Gene's SEGA cartridges carefully, shows interest and understanding in Gene's gaming achievements, asks clarifying questions about the game.
Responds with brief, somewhat dismissive comments like 'They get everybody' and 'I know' without elaboration or deeper insight.
Shows knowledge about Porsche models and options, mentions Phil Wonkerman's purchase confidently.
Fails to recall Phil Wonkerman's birthday, responds vaguely.
Remembers a childhood detail about Elaine that she appreciates.
Opens Elaine's car door for her.
Responds tersely to Elaine's lingering look with 'What.'
Remembers a detail from fourth grade that impresses Elaine.
Asks Elaine out multiple times and they develop a steady relationship.
Unaware that opening Elaine's car door was a defining moment for her.
Distracts himself by focusing on the car's odometer instead of engaging with Elaine's emotional conversation about their relationship.
Calculates the timeline of the relationship and checks the car's odometer to realize he is overdue for an oil change.
Seems distracted and does not directly address the emotional significance of the six-month relationship milestone.
Feels angry and frustrated about being treated unfairly by mechanics but does not direct anger at Elaine.
Is reluctant to express his own feelings due to fear of rejection.
Decides to have the transmission looked at again despite others' opinions, insists on accountability for poor service.
Expresses anger and distrust toward mechanics, showing frustration but also determination to solve the problem.
Responds to Elaine's emotional breakdown with concern and reassurance, saying 'no' when she asks if he thinks she's a fool.
Listens to Elaine and agrees that she needs time, showing patience and understanding.
Initially reacts with inner anger and frustration (inner voice about 'scumballs' and 'warranty'), but does not express this outwardly to Elaine.
Internally prepares to confront a problem confidently, willing to stand up for himself despite anticipating opposition.
Startled and unsure whether his spoken response was to Elaine or his inner voice, showing some confusion but still manages to say the right thing.
Responds supportively to Elaine's emotional distress, showing emotional awareness and adaptability.
Admits to feeling something important to Elaine, looks nervous but sincere, shares a warm smile with her.
Distracted by watching a soccer game and eating Doritos, shows detachment from the earlier emotional moment.
Looks confused and distracted during a serious moment, trying to appear decisive but clearly uncertain.
Acknowledges missing something important and tries to clarify, showing some self-awareness.
Relies on his 'Oval Image' (a mental or imaginary self) for insight but receives no help, indicating a lack of internal confidence or problem-solving ability.
Shares with Gene that he and Elaine 'sort of have this -- thing,' showing openness about his feelings.
Asks Gene if Elaine ever mentioned owning a horse, showing curiosity and consideration about Elaine's interests.
Shrugs off his own question about the horse and changes the subject to the game score, indicating possible avoidance or lack of deeper engagement.
Initiates a conversation with Gene about his relationship with Elaine, showing some social awareness and willingness to communicate.
Asks Gene about Elaine owning a horse, trying to gather information relevant to a situation, indicating some problem-solving effort.
Thinks about the horse question but then shakes it off without pursuing it further, showing a missed opportunity to clarify important details.
Passes the ball and plays casually without showing assertiveness or clear strategy in the game.
Explains the stuck door with a calm, logical explanation and tries to reassure Elaine that the design discourages burglars.
Maintains a facade of knowledge despite clearly not understanding the situation, driven by 'Guy Pride'.
Explains the stuck door using basic physics and tries to rationalize the problem confidently.
Fails to recognize the practical problem that they are trapped inside due to the stuck door.
Maintains a confident front despite lacking real understanding, driven by 'Guy Pride'.
Reassures Elaine about the basement being level and the house being well built.
Dismisses Elaine's suggestion to call Steve for help, implying it's an overreaction.
Inspects the basement carefully with a flashlight, assesses the floor as level and well built, confidently reassures Elaine that the house was a good purchase and everything works as it should.
Dismisses Elaine's suggestion to call Steve immediately about the hot water issue, preferring to wait until there is a 'real problem', showing reluctance to seek help.
Tries to fix the water heater himself despite not knowing much, shows willingness to help.
Does not respond to Elaine's frustration or offer reassurance, just leaves to go to the hardware store.
Identifies the water heater as the problem and attempts to fix it himself.
Makes loud noises and causes a mess in the basement, indicating lack of skill.
Needs to go to the hardware store to get parts, implying he is trying to solve the problem.
Winks at the clerk after receiving instructions, showing a friendly gesture.
Drops the tool kit and chases after the parts, appearing clumsy but sincere.
Complains about Steve and others being naturally skilled and laughing at him, showing insecurity but no hostility.
Winks and says 'Got it' after being warned about the tool set, but then immediately drops it and has to chase down the parts.
Expresses self-awareness about missing out on learning practical skills and feeling less capable than others like Steve.
Feels pain seeing Elaine enchanted by someone else, showing emotional sensitivity.
Tries to help with tools despite not knowing how, showing willingness to contribute.
Makes a self-deprecating joke about his lack of survival skills compared to Steve, showing humility and humor.
Sorting through a 53-piece tool set but has no idea what to do with it.
Acknowledges the problem (latch broke) and listens to Steve's explanation.
Realizes he lacks the necessary tools and skills to fix the problem himself, showing self-awareness.
Puts down the tool kit and allows Steve to take over the repair.
Looks at the kid's battleship with interest and asks Elaine about the kid, showing curiosity and engagement.
Recognizes and appreciates the working battleship made from Coke cans, shows curiosity about the kid.
Asks Elaine if they have a kid, showing some confusion or lack of awareness about the situation.
Watches a basketball game attentively and reacts to the announcer's statistics.
Leans forward intently during the game, showing engagement and focus.
Repeatedly urges the player to succeed ('Come on come on come on comeoncomeon --'), demonstrating emotional investment but no clear skill or strategic thinking.

Expresses frustration about his job and lack of fulfillment, admits he doesn't understand half of what he does, and dismisses the importance of his work (e.g., telling the secretary to put in 'the usual bullshit' in the letter).
Shows self-awareness about his dissatisfaction and desires to pursue something he finds meaningful (hang gliding), indicating some clarity about his own goals.
Is an orthopedic surgeon who is clearly skilled and knowledgeable in his profession.
Expresses frustration with his pager and the interruptions it causes, showing some dissatisfaction with his work-life balance but not incompetence.
Takes initiative to write a screenplay exposing issues in his industry during his limited free time, demonstrating creativity, dedication, and proactive behavior.
Engages in playful conversation with Dave, openly shares personal thoughts about mental delaying techniques during intimacy.
Focuses attention on Elaine under the blanket, showing presence and engagement with partner.
Mentions losing enjoyment in sex and baseball, indicating self-awareness and sincerity.
Uses the Baseball Method as a mental delaying technique, showing ability to focus and apply a strategy.
Acknowledges that the Baseball Method got stale and stopped being enjoyable, showing self-awareness and willingness to adapt.
Switches to math problems as an alternative mental technique, indicating resourcefulness and intellectual engagement.
Admits to struggling with train math problems because he imagines a beautiful girl on the train, specifically Elaine, showing a playful and sincere side.
Gives Dave a close call look before returning to work, indicating a friendly and tolerant interaction.
Admits he cannot solve train math problems because he gets distracted imagining a girl on the train.
Acknowledges his distraction openly and interacts playfully with Elaine about it.
Declines invitation to social gathering citing a vague reason, seems disengaged.
Explains his choice of a new rock as an upgrade, shares information with Elaine and her parents.
Chooses to stay by the fire instead of socializing, citing a vague reason related to ancestors.
Explains the concept of an 'upgrade' to Primate Elaine and her parents, showing understanding of improvement and innovation.
Explains the difference between the items patiently to Elaine.
Refuses to take back the item, insisting all sales are final despite Elaine's request.
Jokingly challenges Elaine's father about who killed dinner, showing a playful side.
Explains the functional purpose of the painted markings on the item, showing some knowledge.
Refuses to take back the item despite the request, citing 'all sales are final', showing adherence to rules but lack of flexibility.
Tries to justify his actions by pointing out he provided dinner, showing some confidence but defensiveness.
Initially resists taking something back, then stops cold and agrees after seeing Elaine's certain look.
Initially resists taking something back, calls the request unreasonable.
Recognizes the situation after being stunned by Elaine's look and agrees to take it back.
Nods in agreement to buying hockey sticks to improve their apartment.
Plays Indoor Death Hockey in a messy, unkempt apartment with newspapers and pizza boxes scattered around.
